notesStmt.note: Two catalog entries pasted on the verso of the front flyleaf; a cutting from a newspaper with the headline "The highest-priced book" pasted on the recto of the first front endleaf
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2036, no. 64.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 109, no. 100.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This late fifteenth-century liturgical manuscript is a Book of Hours for the Use of Rome with a calendar for Flanders, Short Hours of the Holy Spirit and the Cross, a Mass of the Virgin, and the Hours of the Virgin. There are six full-page miniatures with blank versos, face pages with matching foliate borders, and illuminated opening initials.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Rome

supportDesc.extent: iii+145+iii; 125 x 80 mm bound to 135 x 95 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right-hand corner

layoutDesc.layout: One column of fourteen lines; frame-ruled in purple ink with double upper and lower bounding lines; written area: 66 x 43 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Six full-page miniatures with full borders for major text divisions facing text pages with full borders and illuminated initials; four-line illuminated initials for hour divisions within the Hours of the Virgin; red, blue, and gold decorated initials and line fillers throughout; the versos of the miniatures blank and unruled

binding.p: Nineteenth-century diced and blind-tooled Russia leather; stamped in gold on spine: "MISSAL"; marbled paper pastedowns

history.provenance: Petrus Ysermans and Jeronimus Maelens (17th century); W. J. Gilbert, Saint Louis (his sale, Philadelphia, 7 June 1909); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; pasted on to recto of second end leaf, note written on letterhead of the Diocesan Chancery of Saint Louis, written in the hand of W.J. Gilbert: "Father van der Sanden [?] now at the Cathedral, says that the inscription on the next page is Flemish; it is written off below and a translation added by him; W.J.G. May 29/89"; a transcription and translation follow; on the verso of the second end leaf are notes about the manuscript that have been erased, "written on vellum" can still be discerned; on the recto of fol. 1, the inscription "Petrus Ysermans horst toe desen boeck" [This book belongs to Peter Ysermans]; illegible inscription at the top of fol. 1r "G. P[illegible] 12 [illegible]; on a blank page, after the calendar and before the Hours of the Holy Spirit, which begin on the verso, are the signatures of Petrus Ysermans and Jeronimus Maelens (fol. 14r)
